This hotel is being rebranded, transitioning from a Wyndham Garden. At rates ranging from $300 to $400 per night, hotel points enthusiasts may be drawn to this selection given the great return on Wyndham points. Well, once you get there, you might think differently. The microscopic lobby gets crowded even with a few people. Even more absurd, several times I was passing through the lobby, workers were attempting to bring what appeared to be very large laundry or garbage carts through the tiny lobby. Is there no working service elevator or entrance/exit? Speaking of elevators, they are slow, dirty and smelled either strongly of cleaning supplies or urine. I wasn't sure what was worse. Despite seeing cleaning staff in the hallways throughout the day, the hallways were filthy. Cleaning supply carts frequently blocked passage through the narrow hallways. I saw garbage stored in the stairways (pretty sure the NYC fire inspector would not approve of that!). In addition to common area cleanliness issues, I found service at the downstairs restaurant to be inhospitable, even by NYC standards. We went down to get some pre-dinner snacks as we had noticed a few things that looked quite nice on the menu. We stood for 5 minutes next to the sign that stated: please wait to be seated. Several workers passed by us, never even making eye contact. The bartender, standing feet from us, never acknowledged our presence. So, we walked passed the workers who were ignoring us and were finally handed menus and told me could take an outdoor table. So we picked what we wanted to eat and a waiter came up to us and said: I'm not sure why you were handed those menus because we aren't serving food. I was perplexed as I looked around at other people eating food and being served food. He then responded that the kitchen was closed from 4 to 5. All of this could have been prevented by simply being greeted at the door with: Hi guys, our kitchen is closed until 5 but you're welcome to have drinks while you wait. Simple, common customer service prevents so many issues. Needless to say, we walked out. To bad. I really wanted to try those duck confit spring rolls. The good stuff. Front desk staff were friendly and welcoming. While the decor may suggest that this hotel is going for a low-scale W hotel look, there was none of the famous W hotel rudeness. The room itself, although small, was very clean. The decor wasn't my taste but didn't really matter. Street noise was problematic as was hallway noise but that's pretty common in NYC. With a website that conjures up images of globe hopping tourists and luxury, this one is almost a con-job. But since the hotel is obviously in the midst of transition, I'll try to be generous and give two stars.I am scheduled to stay here again in the fall but will probably be cancelling and switching to the nearby Four Points...just a few blocks away. Prices are generally lower, rooms a bit bigger, common areas are cleaner.

I stayed here a couple of years ago when it was bearing the Wyndham name. It's still a Wyndham, and I stayed on points. But there's good news and bad news. The good news is a majorish item, the bad ones are all fairly minor. But there are a lot of them. The hotel has gone to the dark-wall/Edison lightbulb sort of decor that has become so popular. There is less furniture in the rooms than previously, which makes them seem larger, and I think perhaps the bathrooms, which are completely remodeled, are indeed bigger. But if you're bringing much more than a toothbrush, you'll discover there isn't much room for what's in your suitcase. There was one tiny drawer in the shelf-desk, and that was It. Yes, a closet (with a safe in its floor), at least. Where could the suitcase go? Can't put it on top of the heating/AC operation under the window - there's now a fenestrated wooden screen in front of it. A luggage rack? At this point, there are none in the hotel. At all. It seems unclear whether this will be a permanent situation or whether they're On Order. The desk was very apologetic, perhaps a little embarrassed, and offered me a second chair, just like the slightly flimsy Thonet/ice cream parlor-style one at the desk, for my suitcase. In the bathroom, there's no shaving mirror, and the lights go up only one side of the mirror, making odd shadows for putting on makeup. The room was very clean, although the hall didn't seem to be vacuumed daily. I thought the bed extremely comfortable. No lighting over the bed, but tiny pencil spots on each side, although not at a height that made reading easy.  Personnel are very pleasant, and there's now an adjacent restaurant that has a largish, slightly raised terrace open to the street that would be a reasonable place for a drink on a nice day or evening. I understand hotels don't particularly want long-term guests. But when even a carry-on suitcase is a problem in a room, what should we think?

Stayed for 3 nights. Very pleasant and accomodating staff. Comfy beds. But.....lots of construction, noisy staff at 7 AM, dirty hallways, and room supplies that weren't restocked--ever--ruined it. On top of that, many in our large convention group waited up to 3 house for a room after normal check-in time. Not your typical Wyndam experience.

Appalling service. We stayed for 8 nights there during Easter 2017. I had to bring the attention of reception regarding lack of towels and cleanliness on several occasions.One day the room had not even been done. Informed reception but they only replaced the towels and left the beds unmade.I contacted the hotel to make a complaint (via their website) - it has been more than 2 weeks and I have not received any reply, nor via their Facebook page.Try to avoid this hotel at all. Only good feature it is its location but not worth it.

We went to see the Macy's Thanksgiving Parade and take my son for some general sightseeing.We had a two-queen room, and had asked for a second, adjoining room; I'm not sure that the hotel even has adjoining rooms. The rooms are extremely small by common standards, maybe a tad small of average by manhattan standards. The beds were comfortable, the bathroom decently sized, and everything was reasonably updated.

Super nice hotel, freshly renovated with a very urban look, located close to Penn station if you arrive by train. We loved our rooms which were very clean, and we were always greeted with a smile wether we were walking in or out. I recommend it.

It's a great hotel but right now (April 2017) they have an elevator renovation going on, meaning only one out of two elevators is functional. That means the elevator waits are *very* long. Also the A/C was pretty noisy so I switched it off before going to sleep.

This place used to be alright, I've stayed at it a lot and it was a solid "ok, not amazing, clean" hotel in a good location. But they recently remodeled and and rebranded as the "'Hotel Henri" and it seems like they also remodeled the quality of the whole experience downwards.-The new shower doors leak, so there was always a big puddle in my bathroom that I had to clean up every day-One of the two elevators was out of service for what sounded like a planned replacement. So it took 10+ minutes to even get on the elevator at times. Maintenance is acceptable, but no warning was given-The carpets always look dirty because they are black-Front Desk Agent when I was checking out asked "how was your stay?" and I said "horrible" and she responded with "that's great to hear". Obviously she wasn't listening to me-I was given a new shampoo bottle that was dirtyIn summary, they really didn't pay attention to any points of service after the remodel. I know a rep of the hotel will probably come respond with a generic "I'm sorry" message like they always do for these types of complaints on review sites, but this hotel is still fully off my list for the future. Up to 2 points on my rating because the room was an ok size for NYC and some of the staff showed real hustle at times, and the staff knows the hotel has gone downhill from talking to them in the elevator.

We arrived at a transitional time for the hotel (some renovations) which was inevitably evident in some areas....but that didn't affect the welcoming atmosphere - even the workmen were pleasant and always smiling. The location was second to none... a 1 min walk to the 'flatiron', a few blocks from the Empire State Building and Times Square. A $20 taxi ride from both Brooklyn bridge and Central Park. Perfect.Above all, the staff were so nice.... this is the first time I've ever written a review as the staff were brilliant. Genuine and sincerely interested in what you'd been up to..... either that or just good at their jobs... either way... you'll feel welcome here... especially by these guys ......

The hotel was great, front desk and employees in the bar were great. My only complaint was the elevator still had plastic on the floors and the rugs in the halls could use some serious vacuuming. My room was immaculate though and very comfortable bed. Another small inconvenience was the shower took almost 30 minutes to get warm.
